title: Robot Operating System Deployment and Maintenance
content:
--- title: "Robot Operating System Deployment and Maintenance" summary: "Learn how to take your ROS 2 application from your development computer to a real robot and keep it running reliably." tags: [deployment, maintenance, ros2, robotics] keywords: [deployment, maintenance, ros, robotics, launch-files, packaging, debugging, logging] learningObjectives: - "Understand the process of deploying a ROS 2 application." - "Learn how to use launch files to start a complex ROS 2 system." - "Be introduced to tools for debugging and logging in ROS 2." prerequisites: ["ROS 2 Basics"] outcome: "Readers will be able to package, deploy, and maintain a ROS 2 application on a target robot." successCriteria: - "Create a ROS 2 package for a simple application." - "Write a launch file that starts multiple nodes with remapped topics." - "Use `ros2 bag` to record and replay data from a running ROS 2 system." toolsUsed: [ROS 2, colcon, ros2 bag] relatedConcepts: [software-engineering, devops, embedded-systems, system-administration] --- import Prerequisites from '@site/src/components/Prerequisites'; import LearningObjective from '@site/src/components/LearningObjective'; import Outcome from '@site/src/components/Outcome'; import SuccessCriteria from '@site/src/components/SuccessCriteria'; import Exercise from '@site/src/components/Exercise'; import Checkpoint from '@site/src/components/Checkpoint'; # Chapter 4: Robot Operating System Deployment and Maintenance This chapter covers the deployment and maintenance of ROS-based robot systems.

You should have a good understanding of ROS 2 and have written your own ROS 2 nodes and packages.
  • Understand the process of deploying a ROS 2 application.
  • Learn how to use launch files to start a complex ROS 2 system.
  • Be introduced to tools for debugging and logging in ROS 2.
 ## From Development to Deployment So far, you have been running your ROS 2 applications on your development computer. **Deployment** is the process of taking your application and getting it to run on the target robot. This often involves cross-compiling your code for a different architecture (e.g., ARM) and setting up the robot's operating system with the necessary dependencies. ## Launch Files A complex ROS 2 application can consist of dozens of nodes, each with its own set of parameters. Starting all of these nodes manually would be tedious and error-prone. **Launch files** are Python scripts that allow you to start and configure a complete ROS 2 system with a single command. With launch files, you can: - Start multiple nodes. - Set parameters for each node. - Remap topic names. - Group nodes into namespaces. ## Debugging and Logging When things go wrong on a real robot, it can be difficult to figure out what happened. ROS 2 provides a number of tools to help with debugging and logging: - **`ros2 bag`:** A command-line tool for recording and replaying data from a running ROS 2 system. This is incredibly useful for capturing data from a failed experiment and replaying it in a simulator to debug the problem. - **`rqt_console`:** A GUI tool for viewing and filtering log messages from all the nodes in the system.

What is the purpose of a ROS 2 launch file?

Create a ROS 2 package that contains two nodes: a talker and a listener. Write a launch file that starts both nodes and remaps the topic they use to communicate. Run the launch file and verify that the nodes are communicating correctly.

You now have the skills to take your robotics applications out of the lab and into the real world. You can package, deploy, and maintain your ROS 2 systems on real robots.
  • Create a ROS 2 package for a simple application.
  • Write a launch file that starts multiple nodes with remapped topics.
  • Use `ros2 bag` to record and replay data from a running ROS 2 system.
